Award.AwardTitle: o-Phenylenes: Controlled Folding and Directed Oxidative Planarization
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor C. Scott Hartley of the Department of Chemistry & Biochemistry at Miami University (Ohio) is supported in an award from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program for research focusing on the ortho-phenylenes (o-phenylenes). These form a simple class of conjugated polymers that have recently been shown to spontaneously fold into conformations similar to alpha-helices, with aromatic stacking interactions in place of hydrogen bonding. Methods are being developed in this work to control and exploit this folding to give molecules with complex, functional three-dimensional structures. Further, the o-phenylenes are being used as substrates for the synthesis of graphene fragments. Synthetic methods developed as part of this goal should be of broad interest in the bottom-up preparation of graphene nanostructures, and the specific target compounds have been identified as a new class of liquid crystals with board-like structures.

The o-phenylenes, as investigated in this project, link disparate but important areas of organic materials chemistry and nanotechnology. First, non-biological molecules that fold analogously to protein subunits have long been sought because of their potential in areas such as catalysis and energy conversion. Because of their structural simplicity, o-phenylenes may be an important platform to address the challenge of deriving complex, functional structures by assembling smaller folded pieces. Second, graphene is arguably the most important single material under development for future applications in nanoelectronics. Structurally well-defined graphene pieces are important to understanding the basic properties of graphene and have their own applications; in this project, the targets are members of an unusual class of liquid crystals with potential in organic electronics and high performance light valves. Broader impacts of this project include the training students in organic synthesis, liquid crystals characterization, computational chemistry, and various forms of spectroscopy, as well as fundamental concepts in molecular design, conformational analysis, self-assembly, and electronic structure. Some experiments have been designed to have significant pedagogical value for less-experienced researchers; the project includes an outreach effort to get high school teachers involved in the research experience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In nature, molecular structural complexity is almost always generated through folding: long chains fold into well-defined shapes dictated by their composition. This complexity gives rise to the remarkable properties of, for example, enzymes: chemical selectivities and activities that are unmatched by state-of-the-art artificial (non-biological) systems. Taking inspiration from this example, substantial attention has been paid to "foldamers": short chains that fold into well-defined three-dimensional structures by design.

The ortho-phenylenes are a relatively recent addition to the class of non-biological foldamers. They are structurally very simple, consisting of only chains of repeating (flat) aromatic rings that fold into helices (see Figure). While there are many other types of aromatic foldamers, the o-phenylenes offer some very useful features: they are (relatively) easy to synthesize, their folding is straightforward to characterize, and their structural simplicity lends itself to modeling at various levels of complexity.

One overarching goal of this project is to understand and control the folding of o-phenylenes. We have been able to show that they fold because of a particular attraction between aromatic rings (arene–arene stacking), and using this result have been able to build models that predict their behavior. These models have been elaborated to include the effect of the environment (solvent) of the o-phenylene such that we now have a fairly complete understanding of the compounds as a class.

We believe that the most important feature of o-phenylenes is that they are well-suited to incorporation within larger molecular architectures. That is, in nature there are few functional molecules consisting only of helices: to achieve sophisticated function, it is necessary to elaborate these "secondary structures" into more-complex "tertiary" or "quaternary" structures. Because of their simplicity, we have been able to take o-phenylene building blocks and assemble them into large rings. These "macrocycles" raise interesting questions about molecular folding beyond local (intramolecular) interactions and how folding can be integrated into other processes, and also open the door to future applications in, for example, molecular recognition and catalysis.

Another useful feature of o-phenylenes is that they represent precursors to flat molecules based on the structure of graphene. We have been using this to develop new compounds that behave as liquid crystals (ordered fluids). Although molecular shape is one of the most important determinants of the structures of liquid crystal phases, board-like molecules similar to planarized o-phenylenes have received very little attention despite longstanding theoretical attention. In this project, we discovered a new liquid crystal phase that consists of a fluid with the molecules arranged in layers with short-range rectangular positional ordering within the layers. Excitingly, this phase structure is directly attributable to the (unusual) board-like shape of the molecules. Our hope is that phases of this type will form the basis for functional materials that combine good semiconducting characteristics because of the molecular order with the self-assembling and self-healing properties of the liquid crystal state.

We have also been working to develop new teaching labs for college-level sophomore organic chemistry courses that incorporate elements of materials science. The lab developed as part of this project uses liquid crystals as a means to visualize molecular chirality. The term "chiral" refers to objects (including molecules) that are not superimposable on their mirror images; the best example of this is simply one's hands. Molecular chirality is a tremendously important topic, particularly because the two forms of a chiral molecule can have very different biological effects (e.g., in pharmaceuticals). However, illustrating the significance of molecular chirality in a meaningful way is challenging in the teaching lab. So-called "cholesteric" liquid crystals are good examples of chiral materials that exhibit an easily observed macroscopic manifestation of their molecular-level chirality: they selectively reflect opposite polarizations of circularly polarized light depending on the specific molecular mirror image that is used. This is easily observed using the circular polarizers found in common 3D glasses from movie theaters or TVs. In our lab, the students synthesize a chiral compound and use it to induce a cholesteric phase, giving brightly colored textures they can observe with the glasses using the naked eye. The lab strives to make connections between molecular structure and bulk properties used in functional materials.
